instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: Got a board in that has no signs of physical or liquid damage. I get proper 12.58V on PPBUS. After plugged into the MagSafe the TPS IC <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> gets extremely hot. I replaced the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> as well as the 2 MOSFETs and the shorts on the 3v3 rails was removed. However even after replacing those components after plugging the board into power again <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> gets burning hot again. I have visually checked the capacitors on the rails and even removed the 3v3 coil to isolate the issue and am still at a loss.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: Short on PP3v3 and PP5v rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> will only get hot if one of the LDOs has a short, check VREG3, VREG5, VREF2 for short to GND.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground, as is <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. VREG3 and VREF2 are not shorted to ground. Is there a funny name for the VREG5 rail?

Diode mode on VREG3: 0.568 and VREF2: 0.541.

Should I inject voltage on the 5V and 3V3 S5 rails or will that damage sensitive 3V3 components?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: There are so few parts on this rail you can find the short easily. <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> would be suspect number 1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: Got the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> short resolved last night it was <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>, 3V3 is still sorted to ground and after replacing <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> a second time (after resolving the <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> short) <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> is getting hot and I have a 3 Ohm resistance to ground of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: You can only hope the short is caused by <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>, if not then this board probably got fried pretty good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: Yeah I've tried pulling <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> and the short is still present. I'm guessing the client was using a Chinese POS charger and killed this thing. Will I have any luck with injecting current? As of late all I ever seem to get are hot lead wires!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Shorted <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, Green Light No Power
threads.message: You can inject current it's just 99% chance that what gets hot is the CPU. I would go for it and start with 1v and see what happens.
